unnormalised: The Ministry of Education has announced several key updates to its flagship government education schemes, aimed at improving access and quality of education across India. The Samagra Shiksha Abhiyan, allocated a budget of Rs. 37,383 crore for FY 2023-24, will now include provisions for enhanced digital learning resources. Specifically, the initiative aims to equip at least 75% of govt. schools with smart classrooms by 31/03/2025.
normalised: The Ministry of Education has announced several key updates to its flagship government education schemes, aimed at improving access and quality of education across India. The Samagra Shiksha Abhiyan, allocated a budget of rupee thirty seven thousand three hundred and eighty three crore for fiscal year two thousand twenty three to two thousand twenty four, will now include provisions for enhanced digital learning resources. Specifically, the initiative aims to equip at least seventy five percent of government schools with smart classrooms by thirty first march two thousand twenty five.

unnormalised: Furthermore, the National Education Policy (NEP) 2020 implementation is progressing, with significant emphasis on vocational training. Under the Skill India Mission, collaboration between schools and local industries is being fostered to provide students with practical skills relevant to the job market. The target is to integrate vocational courses into the curriculum for students from Class 6 onwards in at least 5000 schools by the end of the academic year.
normalised: Furthermore, the National Education Policy (N-E-P) two thousand twenty implementation is progressing, with significant emphasis on vocational training. Under the Skill India Mission, collaboration between schools and local industries is being fostered to provide students with practical skills relevant to the job market. The target is to integrate vocational courses into the curriculum for students from Class six onwards in at least five thousand schools by the end of the academic year.

unnormalised: The midday meal scheme, now known as PM Poshan, has been revised to include fortified rice and pulses, addressing nutritional deficiencies among students. The scheme currently covers approx. 11.8 crore children across 1.12 million schools. The cost per child has been increased by Rs. 0.50 to ensure better quality and variety in the meals provided.
normalised: The midday meal scheme, now known as P-M Poshan, has been revised to include fortified rice and pulses, addressing nutritional deficiencies among students. The scheme currently covers approximately eleven point eight crore children across one point one two million schools. The cost per child has been increased by rupee zero point five zero to ensure better quality and variety in the meals provided.

unnormalised: Scholarship programs, such as the National Means cum Merit Scholarship (NMMS), will see a 15% increase in the scholarship amount, benefiting over 2 lakh students annually. The application deadline for NMMS has been extended to 30/11/2024. Also, a new scheme called the "Vidya Lakshmi Education Loan Scheme" has been launched for higher education, providing collateral-free loans up to Rs. 7.5 lakh.
normalised: Scholarship programs, such as the National Means cum Merit Scholarship (N-M-M-S), will see a fifteen percent increase in the scholarship amount, benefiting over two lakh students annually. The application deadline for N-M-M-S has been extended to thirtieth november two thousand twenty four. Also, a new scheme called the "Vidya Lakshmi Education Loan Scheme" has been launched for higher education, providing collateral-free loans up to rupee seven point five lakh.

unnormalised: These updates reflect the govt's commitment to transforming the education landscape and ensuring equitable opportunities for all students. Details on application procedures and eligibility criteria for each scheme can be found on the official Ministry of Education website: www.education.gov.in.
